tabbaoth_2807.name: Tabbaoth
tabbaoth_2807.bio: Impressions; rings, “the children of,” returned from the Captivity ([Ezra 2:43](/ezra#Ezra.2.43)).

tabeal_2808.name: Tabeal
tabeal_2808.bio: Goodness of God, the father of one whom the kings of Syria and Samaria in vain attempted to place on the throne of Ahaz ([Isa. 7:6](/isa#Isa.7.6)).

tabeel_2809.name: Tabeel
tabeel_2809.bio: A Persian governor of Samaria, who joined others in the attempt to prevent the rebuilding of Jerusalem ([Ezra 4:7](/ezra#Ezra.4.7)).

tabrimon_2811.name: Tabrimon
tabrimon_2811.bio: Good is Rimmon, the father of Benhadad, king of Syria ([1 Kings 15:18](/1kgs#1Kgs.15.18)).

tahpenes_2817.name: Tahpenes
tahpenes_2817.bio: The wife of Pharaoh, who gave her sister in marriage to Hadad the Edomite ([1 Kings 11:19](/1kgs#1Kgs.11.19), [20](/1kgs#1Kgs.11.20)).

talmai_2818.name: Talmai (Father of three giants)
talmai_2818.bio: One of the Anakim of Hebron, who were slain by the men of Judah under Caleb ([Num. 13:22](/num#Num.13.22); [Josh. 15:14](/josh#Josh.15.14); [Judg.

talmai_2819.name: Talmai (One of the Anakim of Hebron)
talmai_2819.bio: A king of Geshur, to whom Absalom fled after he had put Amnon to death ([2 Sam. 3:3](/2sam#2Sam.3.3); [13:37](/2sam#2Sam.13.37)). His daughter, Maachah, was one of David’s wives, and the mother of Absalom ([1 Chr.

tamar_2821.name: Tamar (daughter of David)
tamar_2821.bio: The daughter-in-law of Judah, to whose eldest son, Er, she was married ([Gen. 38:6](/gen#Gen.38.6)). After her husband’s death, she was married to Onan, his brother (8), and on his death, Judah promised to her that his third son, Shelah, would become her husband.

tamar_2822.name: Tamar (Absalom son of David.)
tamar_2822.bio: A daughter of David ([2 Sam. 13:1-32](/2sam#2Sam.13.1); [1 Chr. 3:9](/1chr#1Chr.3.9)), whom Amnon shamefully outraged and afterwards “hated exceedingly,” thereby illustrating the law of human nature noticed even by the heathen, “Proprium humani ingenii est odisse quem laeseris”, i.e., “It is the property of human nature to hate one whom you have injured.”

tanhumeth_2824.name: Tanhumeth
tanhumeth_2824.bio: Consolation, a Netophathite; one of the captains who supported Gedaliah ([2 Kings 25:23](/2kgs#2Kgs.25.23); [Jer. 40:8](/jer#Jer.40.8)).

tarshish_2828.name: Tarshish (son of Javan)
tarshish_2828.bio: One of the “sons” of Javan ([Gen. 10:4](/gen#Gen.10.4); [1 Chr. 1:7](/1chr#1Chr.1.7)).

tartan_2830.name: Tartan
tartan_2830.bio: One of Sennacherib’s messengers to Hezekiah ([2 Kings 18:17](/2kgs#2Kgs.18.17)).

tatnai_2831.name: Tatnai
tatnai_2831.bio: Gift, a Persian governor (Heb. pehah, i.e., “satrap;” modern “pasha”) “on this side the river”, i.e., of the whole tract on the west of the Euphrates. This Hebrew title pehah is given to governors of provinces generally.

temeni_2840.name: Temeni
temeni_2840.bio: One of the sons of Ashur, the father of Tekoa ([1 Chr. 4:6](/1chr#1Chr.4.6)).

terah_2841.name: Terah
terah_2841.bio: The wanderer; loiterer, for some unknown reason emigrated with his family from his native mountains in the north to the plains of Mesopotamia. He had three sons, Haran, Nahor, and Abraham, and one daughter, Sarah. He settled in “Ur of the Chaldees,” where his son Haran died, leaving behind him his son Lot.

teresh_2842.name: Teresh
teresh_2842.bio: Severe, a eunuch or chamberlain in the palace of Ahasuerus, who conspired with another to murder him. The plot was detected by Mordecai, and the conspirators were put to death ([Esther 2:21](/esth#Esth.2.21); [6:2](/esth#Esth.6.2)).

tertullus_2844.name: Tertullus
tertullus_2844.bio: a modification of "Tertius;" a Roman advocate, whom the Jews employed to state their case against Paul in the presence of Felix ( Acts 24:1-9 ). The charges he adduced against the apostle were, "First, that he created disturbances among the Romans throughout the empire, an offence against the Roman government (crimen majestatis). Secondly, that he was a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes; disturbed the Jews in the exercise of their religion, guaranteed by the state; introduced new gods, a thing prohibited by the Romans.

thahash_2845.name: Thahash
thahash_2845.bio: A badger, a son of Nahor, Abraham’s brother ([Gen. 22:24](/gen#Gen.22.24)).

theophilus_2849.name: Theophilus
theophilus_2849.bio: lover of God, a Christian, probably a Roman, to whom Luke dedicated both his Gospel ( Luke 1:3 ) and the Acts of the Apostles ( 1:1 ). Nothing beyond this is known of him. From the fact that Luke applies to him the title "most excellent", the same title Paul uses in addressing Felix ( Acts 23:26 ; 24:3 ) and Festus ( 26:25 ), it has been concluded that Theophilus was a person of rank, perhaps a Roman officer.

theudas_2850.name: Theudas
theudas_2850.bio: thanksgiving, referred to by Gamaliel in his speech before the council at Jerusalem ( Acts 5:36 ). He headed an insurrection against the Roman authority. Beyond this nothing is known of him.

thomas_2851.name: Thomas
thomas_2851.bio: twin, one of the twelve ( Matthew 10:3 ; Mark 3:18 , etc.). He was also called Didymus ( John 11:16 ; 20:24 ), which is the Greek equivalent of the Hebrew name. All we know regarding him is recorded in the fourth Gospel ( John 11:15 John 11:16 ; John 14:4 John 14:5 ; John 20:24 John 20:25 John 20:26-29 ).

tiberius_2852.name: Tiberius
tiberius_2852.bio: I.e., as known in Roman history, Tiberius Claudius Nero, only mentioned in [Luke 3:1](/luke#Luke.3.1). He was the stepson of Augustus, whom he succeeded on the throne, A.D. 14.

tibni_2853.name: Tibni
tibni_2853.bio: Building of Jehovah, the son of Ginath, a man of some position, whom a considerable number of the people chose as monarch. For the period of four years he contended for the throne with Omri ([1 Kings 16:21](/1kgs#1Kgs.16.21), [22](/1kgs#1Kgs.16.22)), who at length gained the mastery, and became sole monarch of Israel.

tidal_2854.name: Tidal
tidal_2854.bio: (in the LXX. called “Thorgal”), styled the “king of nations” ([Gen. 14:1-9](/gen#Gen.14.1)).

tikvah_2855.name: Tikvah (Hilkiah and those the king had sent with)

tilgath-pilneser_2376.name: Tilgath-pilneser
tilgath-pilneser_2376.bio: An Assyrian king. It has been a question whether he was identical with Tiglath-pileser III. (q.v.), or was his predecessor.

timaeus_2858.name: Timaeus
timaeus_2858.bio: Defiled, the father of blind Bartimaeus ([Mark 10:46](/mark#Mark.10.46)).

timon_2862.name: Timon
timon_2862.bio: honouring, one of the seven deacons at Jerusalem ( Acts 6:5 ). Nothing further is known of him.

timotheus_2863.name: Timotheus
timotheus_2863.bio: the Greek form of the name of Timothy ( Acts 16:1 , etc.; the RSV always "Timothy").

tiras_2864.name: Tiras
tiras_2864.bio: The youngest of the sons of Japheth ([Gen. 10:2](/gen#Gen.10.2); [1 Chr. 1:5](/1chr#1Chr.1.5)).

tirhakah_2865.name: Tirhakah
tirhakah_2865.bio: The last king of Egypt of the Ethiopian (the fifteenth) dynasty. He was the brother-in-law of So (q.v.). He probably ascended the throne about B.C.

tirzah_2868.name: Tirzah
tirzah_2868.bio: The youngest of Zelophehad’s five daughters ([Num. 26:33](/num#Num.26.33); [Josh. 17:3](/josh#Josh.17.3)).

titus_2869.name: Titus
titus_2869.bio: Honourable, was with Paul and Barnabas at Antioch, and accompanied them to the council at Jerusalem ([Gal. 2:1-3](/gal#Gal.2.1); [Acts 15:2](/acts#Acts.15.2)), although his name nowhere occurs in the Acts of the Apostles. He appears to have been a Gentile, and to have been chiefly engaged in ministering to Gentiles; for Paul sternly refused to have him circumcised, inasmuch as in his case the cause of gospel liberty was at stake.

tobadonijah_2870.name: Tobadonijah
tobadonijah_2870.bio: Good is Jehovah, my Lord, a Levite sent out by Jehoshaphat to instruct the people of Judah in the law ([2 Chr. 17:8](/2chr#2Chr.17.8)).

tobiah_2872.name: Tobiah (disturbed that someone)
tobiah_2872.bio: Pleasing to Jehovah, the “servant,” the “Ammonite,” who joined with those who opposed the rebuilding of Jerusalem after the Exile ([Neh. 2:10](/neh#Neh.2.10)). He was a man of great influence, which he exerted in opposition to the Jews, and “sent letters” to Nehemiah “to put him in fear” ([Neh.

tobijah_2873.name: Tobijah (the Levite)
tobijah_2873.bio: Id., a Levite sent out through Judah by Jehoshaphat to teach the people ([2 Chr. 17:8](/2chr#2Chr.17.8)).

togarmah_2875.name: Togarmah
togarmah_2875.bio: A son of Gomer, and grandson of Japheth ([Gen. 10:3](/gen#Gen.10.3)).

toi_2877.name: Toi
toi_2877.bio: A king of Hamath, who sent “Joram his son unto King David to salute him,” when he “heard that David had smitten all the host of Hadadezer” ([2 Sam. 8:9](/2sam#2Sam.8.9), [10](/2sam#2Sam.8.10)). Called Tou ([1 Chr.

tola_2879.name: Tola (son of Puah)
tola_2879.bio: A judge of the tribe of Issachar who “judged” Israel twenty-three years ([Judg. 10:1](/judg#Judg.10.1), [2](/judg#Judg.10.2)), when he died, and was buried in Shamir. He was succeeded by Jair.

trophimus_2880.name: Trophimus
trophimus_2880.bio: a foster-child, an Ephesian who accompanied Paul during a part of his third missionary journey ( Acts 20:4 ; 21:29 ). He was with Paul in Jerusalem, and the Jews, supposing that the apostle had brought him with him into the temple, raised a tumult which resulted in Paul's imprisonment. (See TEMPLE, HEROD'S.) In writing to Timothy, the apostle says, "Trophimus have I left at Miletum sick" ( 2�Timothy 4:20 ).

tubal-cain_2884.name: Tubal-cain
tubal-cain_2884.bio: The son of Lamech and Zillah, “an instructor of every artificer in brass and iron” ([Gen. 4:22](/gen#Gen.4.22); R.V., “the forger of every cutting instrument of brass and iron”).

tychicus_2885.name: Tychicus
tychicus_2885.bio: chance, an Asiatic Christian, a "faithful minister in the Lord" ( Ephesians 6:21 Ephesians 6:22 ), who, with Trophimus, accompanied Paul on a part of his journey from Macedonia to Jerusalem ( Acts 20:4 ). He is alluded to also in Colossians 4:7 , Titus 3:12 , and 2�Timothy 4:12 as having been with Paul at Rome, whence he sent him to Ephesus, probably for the purpose of building up and encouraging the church there.

tyrannus_2886.name: Tyrannus
tyrannus_2886.bio: prince, a Greek rhetorician, in whose "school" at Ephesus Paul disputed daily for the space of two years with those who came to him ( Acts 19:9 ). Some have supposed that he was a Jew, and that his "school" was a private synagogue.
